Some of ’em ’s worth twenty dollars apiece — there ai n’t any , hardly , but ’s worth six bits or a dollar . ” “[0-i] No ! Is that so ? ” “[1553-di’monds] Cert’nly — anybody’ll tell [you]45-huck so . Hain’t [you]45-huck ever seen one , [Huck]45-huck ? ” “[45-huck] Not as [I]0-i remember . ” “[45-huck] Oh , [kings]1554-kings have slathers of [them]1554-kings . ” “[1554-kings] Well , [I]0-i don ’ know [no kings]1555-no kings , [Tom]46-tom . ” “[46-tom] [I]0-i reckon [you]45-huck do n’t . Like [that old humpbacked Richard]149-that old humpbacked richard . ” “[149-that old humpbacked richard] [Richard]149-that old humpbacked richard ? Only if [you]46-tom get married [I]0-i ’ll be more lonesomer than ever . ” “[0-i] No [you]46-tom wo n’t . [You]46-tom ’ll come and live with [me]0-i . Now stir out of this and [we]1575-we ’ll go to digging . ” [They]1575-we worked and sweated for half an hour . No result . [They]1575-we toiled another halfhour . Still no result . [Huck]45-huck said : “[1576-they] Do [they]1576-they always bury it as deep as this ? ” “[1576-they] Sometimes — not always . Not generally . [I]0-i reckon [we]1575-we have n’t got the right place . ” So [they]1575-we chose [a new spot]2692-a new spot and began again . The labor dragged a little , but still [they]1575-we made progress . [They]1575-we pegged away in silence for some time . Finally [Huck]45-huck leaned on [his]45-huck shovel , swabbed the beaded drops from [his]45-huck brow with [his]45-huck sleeve , and said : “[0-i] Where [you]46-tom going to dig next , after [we]1575-we get this one ? ” “[46-tom] [I]0-i reckon maybe [we]1575-we ’ll tackle the old tree that ’s over yonder on [[Cardiff Hill]4-cardiff hill back of [the widow]1578-the widow ’s]1577-cardiff hill back of the widow ’s . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i reckon that ’ll be a good one . What do [you]46-tom think ? ” “[46-tom] It is mighty curious , [Huck]45-huck . [I]0-i do n’t understand it . Sometimes [witches]767-witches interfere . Let ’s hide the tools in the bushes . ” [The boys]2054-the boys were [there]2038-there that night , about the appointed time . [They]2054-the boys sat in the shadow waiting . It was [a lonely place]2600-a lonely place , and an hour made solemn by old traditions . [Spirits]150-spirits whispered in the rustling leaves , ghosts lurked in [the murky nooks]2696-the murky nooks , the deep baying of a hound floated up out of the distance , an owl answered with [his]2697-his sepulchral note . [The boys]2054-the boys were subdued by these solemnities , and talked little . By and by [they]2054-the boys judged that twelve had come ; [they]2054-the boys marked where the shadow fell , and began to dig . [Their]2054-the boys hopes commenced to rise . [Their]2054-the boys interest grew stronger , and [[their]2054-the boys industry]2699-their industry kept pace with it . The hole deepened and still deepened , but every time [their]2054-the boys hearts jumped to hear the pick strike upon something , [they]2054-the boys only suffered a new disappointment . It was only a stone or a chunk . At last [Tom]46-tom said : “[0-i] It ai n’t any use , [Huck]45-huck , [we]1588-we ’re wrong again . ” “[1588-we] Well , but [we]1588-we _ ca n’t _ be wrong . Like enough it was too late or too early . ” [Huck]45-huck dropped [his]45-huck shovel . “[45-huck] That ’s it , ” said [he]45-huck . “[45-huck] That ’s the very trouble . [We]1588-we got to give this one up . [We]1588-we ca n’t ever tell the right time , and besides this kind of thing ’s too awful , here this time of night with [witches]767-witches and ghosts a - fluttering around so . CHAPTER XXVI About noon the next day [the boys]2054-the boys arrived at the dead tree ; [they]2054-the boys had come for [their]2054-the boys tools . [Tom]46-tom was impatient to go to [the haunted house]2705-the haunted house ; [Huck]45-huck was measurably so , also — but suddenly said : “[0-i] Lookyhere , [Tom]46-tom , do [you]46-tom know what day it is ? ” [Tom]46-tom mentally ran over the days of the week , and then quickly lifted [his]46-tom eyes with a startled look in them — “[0-i] [My]0-i ! [I]0-i never once thought of it , [Huck]45-huck ! ” “[45-huck] Well , [I]0-i did n’t neither , but all at once it popped onto [me]0-i that it was Friday . ” “[45-huck] Blame it , a body ca n’t be too careful , [Huck]45-huck . [We]1613-we might ’ a ’ got into an awful scrape , tackling such a thing on a Friday . ” “[1613-we] _ Might _ ! Better say [we]1613-we _ would _ ! There ’s some lucky days , maybe , but Friday ai n’t . ” “[1614-any fool] [Any fool]1614-any fool knows that . [I]0-i do n’t reckon _ [you]45-huck _ was [the first that found it out]1615-the first that found it out , [Huck]45-huck . ” “[45-huck] Well , [I]0-i never said [I]0-i was , did [I]0-i ? And Friday ai n’t all , neither . [I]0-i had a rotten bad dream last night — dreampt about rats . ” “[0-i] No ! Sure sign of trouble . Did [they]1616-they fight ? ” “[1616-they] No . ” “[1616-they] Well , that ’s good , [Huck]45-huck . When [they]1616-they do n’t fight it ’s only a sign that there ’s trouble around , [you]45-huck know . All [we]1613-we got to do is to look mighty sharp and keep out of it . [We]1613-we ’ll drop this thing for today , and play . Do [you]45-huck know [Robin Hood]91-robin hood , [Huck]45-huck ? ” “[91-robin hood] No . Who ’s [Robin Hood]91-robin hood ? ” “[91-robin hood] Why , [he]91-robin hood was [one of [the greatest men that was ever in [England]7-england]1618-the greatest men that was ever in england]1617-one of the greatest men that was ever in england — and the best . [He]91-robin hood was [a robber]1619-a robber . ” “[1619-a robber] [Cracky]151-cracky , [I]0-i wisht [I]0-i was . Who did [he]91-robin hood rob ? ” “[1619-a robber] Only [sheriffs]1620-sheriffs and [bishops]1621-bishops and [rich people]1622-rich people and [kings]1554-kings , and such like . But [he]91-robin hood never bothered [the poor]2097-the poor . [He]91-robin hood loved [’em]1625-’em . [He]91-robin hood always divided up with ’em perfectly square . ” “[91-robin hood] Well , [he]91-robin hood must ’ a ’ been a brick . ” “[91-robin hood] [I]0-i bet [you]1626-you [he]91-robin hood was , [Huck]45-huck . Oh , [he]91-robin hood was [the noblest man that ever was]1627-the noblest man that ever was . [They]1628-they ai n’t [any such men]1629-any such men now , [I]0-i can tell [you]1626-you . [He]91-robin hood could lick [any man in [England]7-england]1630-any man in england , with one hand tied behind [him]91-robin hood ; and [he]91-robin hood could take [his]91-robin hood yew bow and plug a ten - cent piece every time , a mile and a half . ” “[91-robin hood] What ’s a _ yew _ bow ? ” “[0-i] [I]0-i do n’t know . [It]1631-it ’s some kind of a bow , of course . And if [he]91-robin hood hit that dime only on the edge [he]91-robin hood would set down and cry — and curse . But [we]1632-they ’ll play [Robin Hood]91-robin hood — it ’s nobby fun . [I]0-i ’ll learn [you]1626-you . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i ’m agreed . ” So [they]1632-they played [Robin Hood]91-robin hood all the afternoon , now and then casting a yearning eye down upon [the haunted house]2705-the haunted house and passing a remark about the morrow ’s prospects and possibilities there . As the sun began to sink into the west [they]1632-they took [their]1632-they way homeward athwart the long shadows of the trees and soon were buried from sight in [the forests of [Cardiff Hill]4-cardiff hill]2710-the forests of cardiff hill . On Saturday , shortly after noon , [the boys]2054-the boys were at the dead tree again . [They]2054-the boys had a smoke and a chat in the shade , and then dug a little in [their]2054-the boys last hole , not with great hope , but merely because [Tom]46-tom said there were so many cases where [people]756-people had given up a treasure after getting down within six inches of it , and then [somebody else]2713-somebody else had come along and turned it up with a single thrust of a shovel . The thing failed this time , however , so [the boys]2054-the boys shouldered [their]2054-the boys tools and went away feeling that [they]2054-the boys had not trifled with fortune , but had fulfilled all the requirements that belong to the business of treasure - hunting . When [they]1632-they reached [the haunted house]2705-the haunted house there was something so weird and grisly about the dead silence that reigned there under the baking sun , and something so depressing about the loneliness and desolation of [the place]791-the place , that [they]1632-they were afraid , for a moment , to venture in . Then [they]1632-they crept to the door and took a trembling peep . [They]1632-they saw [a weedgrown , floorless room]2717-a weedgrown , floorless room , unplastered , an ancient fireplace , vacant windows , [a ruinous staircase]2718-a ruinous staircase ; and here , there , and everywhere hung ragged and abandoned cobwebs . [They]1632-they presently entered , softly , with quickened pulses , talking in whispers , ears alert to catch the slightest sound , and muscles tense and ready for instant retreat . In a little while familiarity modified [their]1632-they fears and [they]1632-they gave [the place]791-the place a critical and interested examination , rather admiring [their]1632-they own boldness , and wondering at it , too . Next [they]1632-they wanted to look [upstairs]619-upstairs . This was something like cutting off retreat , but [they]1632-they got to daring [each other]227-each other , and of course there could be but one result — [they]1632-they threw [their]1632-they tools into a corner and made the ascent . Up there were the same signs of decay . In one corner [they]1632-they found [a closet that promised mystery]2722-a closet that promised mystery , but the promise was a fraud — there was nothing in it . [Their]1632-they courage was up now and well in hand . [They]1632-they were about to go down and begin work when — “[0-i] Sh ! ” said [Tom]46-tom . “[0-i] What is it ? ” whispered [Huck]45-huck , blanching with fright . “[0-i] Sh ! ... There ! ... Hear it ? ” “[45-huck] Yes ! ... Oh , [my]0-i ! Let ’s run ! ” “[0-i] Keep still ! Do n’t [you]1633-you budge ! [They]1634-they ’re coming right toward the door . ” [The boys]2054-the boys stretched [themselves]2054-the boys upon the floor with [their]2054-the boys eyes to knotholes in the planking , and lay waiting , in a misery of fear . “[1634-they] [They]1634-they ’ve stopped .... No — coming .... Here [they]1634-they are . Do n’t whisper another word , [Huck]45-huck . [My]0-i goodness , [I]0-i wish [I]0-i was out of this ! ” [Two men]2724-two men entered . [Each boy]840-each boy said to [himself]840-each boy : “[45-huck] There ’s [the old deaf and dumb Spaniard]1635-the old deaf and dumb spaniard that ’s been about [town]526-town once or twice lately — never saw [t’other man]1637-t’other man before . ” “[1635-the old deaf and dumb spaniard] T’other ” was a ragged , unkempt creature , with nothing very pleasant in [his]1637-t’other man face . [The Spaniard]152-the spaniard was wrapped in a serape ; [he]152-the spaniard had bushy white whiskers ; long white hair flowed from under [his]152-the spaniard sombrero , and [he]152-the spaniard wore green goggles . When [they]2724-two men came in , “[45-huck] t’other ” was talking in a low voice ; [they]2724-two men sat down on the ground , facing the door , with [their]2724-two men backs to the wall , and [the speaker]2726-the speaker continued [his]2726-the speaker remarks . [His]2726-the speaker manner became less guarded and [his]2726-the speaker words more distinct as [he]2726-the speaker proceeded : “[45-huck] No , ” said [he]2726-the speaker , “[45-huck] [I]0-i ’ve thought it all over , and [I]0-i do n’t like it . It ’s dangerous . ” “[45-huck] Dangerous ! ” grunted [the “[45-huck] deaf and dumb ” Spaniard]2727-the “ deaf and dumb ” spaniard — to the vast surprise of [the boys]2054-the boys . “[153-milksop] [Milksop]153-milksop ! ” This voice made [the boys]2054-the boys gasp and quake . It was Injun [Joe]100-injun joe ’s ! There was silence for some time . Then [Joe]100-injun joe said : “[153-milksop] What ’s any more dangerous than that job up yonder — but nothing ’s come of it . ” “[153-milksop] That ’s different . Away up [the river]346-the river so , and not another house about . ’ Twon’t ever be known that [we]1639-we tried , anyway , long as [we]1639-we did n’t succeed . ” “[0-i] Well , what ’s more dangerous than coming here in the daytime!—anybody would suspicion [us]1639-we that saw [us]1639-we . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i know that . But there warn’t any other place as handy after that fool of a job . [I]0-i want to quit [this shanty]1640-this shanty . [I]0-i wanted to yesterday , only it warn’t any use trying to stir out of here , with [those infernal boys]1641-those infernal boys playing over there on [the hill]2700-the hill right in full view . ” “[1641-those infernal boys] [Those infernal boys]1641-those infernal boys ” quaked again under the inspiration of this remark , and thought how lucky it was that [they]1641-those infernal boys had remembered it was Friday and concluded to wait a day . [They]1641-those infernal boys wished in [their]1641-those infernal boys hearts [they]1641-those infernal boys had waited a year . [The two men]2730-the two men got out some food and made a luncheon . After a long and thoughtful silence , [Injun Joe]100-injun joe said : “[1641-those infernal boys] Look here , [lad]1644-lad — [you]1644-lad go back up [the river]346-the river where [you]1644-lad belong . Wait there till [you]1644-lad hear from [me]0-i . [I]0-i ’ll take the chances on dropping into [this town]2162-this town just once more , for a look . [We]1647-we ’ll do that ‘ dangerous ’ job after [I]0-i ’ve spied around a little and think things look well for it . Then for [Texas]34-texas ! [We]1647-we ’ll leg it together ! ” This was satisfactory . [Both men]2731-both men presently fell to yawning , and [Injun Joe]100-injun joe said : “[0-i] [I]0-i ’m dead for sleep ! It ’s [your]1644-lad turn to watch . ” [He]100-injun joe curled down in the weeds and soon began to snore . [[His]100-injun joe comrade]796-his comrade stirred [him]100-injun joe once or twice and [he]100-injun joe became quiet . Presently [the watcher]2733-the watcher began to nod ; [his]2733-the watcher head drooped lower and lower , [both men]2731-both men began to snore now . [The boys]2054-the boys drew a long , grateful breath . [Tom]46-tom whispered : “[1644-lad] Now ’s [our]1647-we chance — come ! ” [Huck]45-huck said : “[0-i] [I]0-i can’t — [I’d]0-i die if [they]1648-they was to wake . ” [Tom]46-tom urged — [Huck]45-huck held back . At last [Tom]46-tom rose slowly and softly , and started alone . But the first step [he]46-tom made wrung such a hideous creak from the crazy floor that [he]46-tom sank down almost dead with fright . [He]46-tom never made a second attempt . [The boys]2054-the boys lay there counting the dragging moments till it seemed to [them]2054-the boys that time must be done and eternity growing gray ; and then [they]2054-the boys were grateful to note that at last the sun was setting . Now one snore ceased . [Injun Joe]100-injun joe sat up , stared around — smiled grimly upon [[his]100-injun joe comrade]796-his comrade , whose head was drooping upon [his]796-his comrade knees — stirred [him]100-injun joe up with [his]796-his comrade foot and said : “[0-i] [Here]551-here ! _ [You]551-here ’re _ [a watchman]1650-a watchman , ai n’t [you]551-here ! All right , though — nothing ’s happened . ” “[0-i] [My]0-i ! have [I]0-i been asleep ? ” “[0-i] Oh , partly , partly . Nearly time for [us]1651-we to be moving , [pard]1652-pard . What ’ll [we]1651-we do with what little swag [we]1651-we ’ve got left ? ” “[0-i] [I]0-i do n’t know — leave it here as [we]1651-we ’ve always done , [I]0-i reckon . No use to take it away till [we]1651-we start [south]1653-south . Six hundred and fifty in silver ’s something to carry . ” “[0-i] Well — all right — it wo n’t matter to come here once more . ” “[0-i] No — but [I]0-i ’d say come in the night as [we]1651-we used to do — it ’s better . ” “[0-i] Yes : but look here ; it may be a good while before [I]0-i get the right chance at that job ; accidents might happen ; ’ tain’t in such a very good place ; [we]1651-we ’ll just regularly bury it — and bury it deep . ” “[1654-you] Good idea , ” said [the comrade]2738-the comrade , who walked across [the room]190-the room , knelt down , raised one of the rearward hearth - stones and took out a bag that jingled pleasantly . [He]2738-the comrade subtracted from it twenty or thirty dollars for [himself]2738-the comrade and as much for [Injun Joe]100-injun joe , and passed the bag to [the latter]433-the latter , who was on [his]2738-the comrade knees in the corner , now , digging with [his]2738-the comrade bowie - knife . [The boys]2054-the boys forgot all [their]2054-the boys fears , all [their]2054-the boys miseries in an instant . With gloating eyes [they]2054-the boys watched every movement . Luck!—the splendor of it was beyond all imagination ! Six hundred dollars was money enough to make [half a dozen boys]2742-half a dozen boys rich ! [Here]551-here was treasure - hunting under the happiest auspices — there would not be any bothersome uncertainty as to where to dig . [They]2054-the boys nudged [each other]227-each other every moment — eloquent nudges and easily understood , for [they]2054-the boys simply meant—“Oh[1654-you] , but ai n’t [you]1654-you glad _ now _ [we]1651-we ’re here ! ” [Joe]100-injun joe ’s knife struck upon something . “[1654-you] Hello ! ” said [he]100-injun joe . “[1654-you] What is it ? ” said [[his]100-injun joe comrade]796-his comrade . “[1654-you] Half - rotten plank — no , it ’s a box , [I]0-i believe . Here — bear a hand and [we]1651-we ’ll see what it ’s here for . Never mind , [I]0-i ’ve broke a hole . ” [He]100-injun joe reached [his]100-injun joe hand in and drew it out — “[0-i] [Man]866-man , it ’s money ! ” [The two men]2730-the two men examined the handful of coins . [They]2747-they were gold . [The boys above]2748-the boys above were as excited as [themselves]2748-the boys above , and as delighted . [[Joe]100-injun joe ’s comrade]2749-joe ’s comrade said : “[1651-we] [We]1651-we ’ll make quick work of this . There ’s an old rusty pick over amongst the weeds in the corner the other side of the fireplace — [I]0-i saw it a minute ago . ” [He]2749-joe ’s comrade ran and brought [the boys]2054-the boys ’ pick and shovel . [Injun Joe]100-injun joe took the pick , looked it over critically , shook [his]100-injun joe head , muttered something to [himself]100-injun joe , and then began to use it . The box was soon unearthed . It was not very large ; it was iron bound and had been very strong before the slow years had injured it . [The men]810-the men contemplated the treasure awhile in blissful silence . “[0-i] Pard , there ’s thousands of dollars here , ” said [Injun Joe]100-injun joe . “[0-i] ’ Twas always said that [Murrel]154-murrel ’s gang used to be around here one summer , ” [the stranger]240-the stranger observed . “[154-murrel] [I]0-i know it , ” said [Injun Joe]100-injun joe ; “[0-i] and this looks like it , [I]0-i should say . ” “[0-i] Now [you]0-i wo n’t need to do that job . ” [The halfbreed]2753-the halfbreed frowned . Said [he]2753-the halfbreed : “[0-i] [You]0-i do n’t know [me]0-i . Least [you]0-i do n’t know all about that thing . ’ Tain’t robbery altogether — it ’s _ revenge _ ! ” and a wicked light flamed in [his]2753-the halfbreed eyes . “[0-i] [I]0-i ’ll need [your]0-i help in it . When it ’s finished — then [Texas]34-texas . Go [home]197-home to [[your]0-i Nance]1657-your nance and [[your]0-i kids]1658-your kids , and stand by till [you]0-i hear from [me]0-i . ” “[0-i] Well — if [you]0-i say so ; what ’ll [we]1659-we do with this — bury it again ? ” “[155-the great sachem] Yes . [ Ravishing delight overhead . ] _ No _ ! by [the great Sachem]155-the great sachem , no ! [ Profound distress overhead . ] [I]0-i ’d nearly forgot . That pick had fresh earth on it ! [ [The boys]2054-the boys were sick with terror in a moment . ] What business has a pick and a shovel here ? What business with fresh earth on [them]1661-them ? Who brought [them]1661-them here — and where are [they]1661-them gone ? Have [you]0-i heard anybody?—seen [anybody]203-anybody ? What ! bury it again and leave [them]203-anybody to come and see the ground disturbed ? Not exactly — not exactly . [We]1659-we ’ll take it to [[my]0-i den]1663-my den . ” “[1659-we] Why , of course ! Might have thought of that before . [You]0-i mean Number One ? ” “[0-i] No — Number Two — under the cross . [The other place]1664-the other place is bad — too common . ” “[0-i] All right . It ’s nearly dark enough to start . ” [Injun Joe]100-injun joe got up and went about from window to window cautiously peeping out . Presently [he]100-injun joe said : “[0-i] Who could have brought those tools [here]551-here ? Do [you]2054-the boys reckon [they]1661-them can be [upstairs]619-upstairs ? ” [The boys]2054-the boys ’ breath forsook [them]1661-them . [Injun Joe]100-injun joe put [his]100-injun joe hand on [his]100-injun joe knife , halted a moment , undecided , and then turned toward [the stairway]2755-the stairway . [The boys]2054-the boys thought of [the closet]301-the closet , but [their]2054-the boys strength was gone . The steps came creaking up the stairs — the intolerable distress of the situation woke [the stricken resolution of [the lads]1157-the lads]2758-the stricken resolution of the lads — [they]2054-the boys were about to spring for [the closet]301-the closet , when there was a crash of rotten timbers and [Injun Joe]100-injun joe landed on the ground amid the debris of [the ruined stairway]2761-the ruined stairway . [He]100-injun joe gathered [himself]100-injun joe up cursing , and [[his]100-injun joe comrade]796-his comrade said : “[2054-the boys] Now what ’s the use of all that ? If it ’s [anybody]203-anybody , and [they]203-anybody ’re up [there]2038-there , let [them]203-anybody _ stay _ there — who cares ? If [they]203-anybody want to jump down , now , and get into trouble , who objects ? It will be dark in fifteen minutes — and then let [them]203-anybody follow [us]1669-they if [they]203-anybody want to . [I]0-i ’m willing . In [my]0-i opinion , whoever hove those things in here caught a sight of [us]1669-they and took [us]1669-they for ghosts or devils or something . [I]0-i ’ll bet [they]203-anybody ’re running yet . ” [Joe]100-injun joe grumbled awhile ; then [he]100-injun joe agreed with [[his]100-injun joe friend]2763-his friend that what daylight was left ought to be economized in getting things ready for leaving . Shortly afterward [they]1669-they slipped out of [the house]332-the house in the deepening twilight , and moved toward [the river]346-the river with [their]1669-they precious box . [Tom]46-tom and [Huck]45-huck rose up , weak but vastly relieved , and stared after [them]1669-they through the chinks between the logs of [the house]332-the house . Follow ? Not [they]1669-they . [They]1669-they were content to reach [ground]2767-ground again without broken necks , and take [the townward track]2768-the townward track over [the hill]2700-the hill . [They]1669-they did not talk much . [They]1669-they were too much absorbed in hating [themselves]1669-they — hating the ill luck that made [them]1669-they take the spade and the pick there . But for that , [Injun Joe]100-injun joe never would have suspected . [He]100-injun joe would have hidden the silver with the gold to wait there till [his]100-injun joe “[203-anybody] revenge ” was satisfied , and then [he]100-injun joe would have had the misfortune to find that money turn up missing . Bitter , bitter luck that the tools were ever brought [there]2038-there ! [They]1669-they resolved to keep a lookout for [that Spaniard]2771-that spaniard when [he]1670-he should come to [town]526-town spying out for chances to do [his]1670-he revengeful job , and follow [him]1670-he to “[1670-he] Number Two , ” wherever that might be . Then a ghastly thought occurred to [Tom]46-tom . “[1670-he] Revenge ? What if [he]1670-he means _ [us]1671-us _ , [Huck]45-huck ! ” “[45-huck] Oh , do n’t ! ” said [Huck]45-huck , nearly fainting . [They]1669-they talked it all over , and as [they]1669-they entered [town]526-town [they]1669-they agreed to believe that [he]1670-he might possibly mean [somebody else]2713-somebody else — at least that [he]1670-he might at least mean [nobody]647-nobody but [Tom]46-tom , since only [Tom]46-tom had testified . Very , very small comfort it was to [Tom]46-tom to be alone in danger ! [Company]412-company would be a palpable improvement , [he]46-tom thought . CHAPTER XXVII The adventure of the day mightily tormented [Tom]46-tom ’s dreams that night . Four times [he]46-tom had [his]46-tom hands on that rich treasure and four times it wasted to nothingness in [his]46-tom fingers as sleep forsook [him]46-tom and wakefulness brought back the hard reality of [his]46-tom misfortune . As [he]46-tom lay in the early morning recalling the incidents of [his]46-tom great adventure , [he]46-tom noticed that they seemed curiously subdued and far away — somewhat as if they had happened in [another world]2777-another world , or in a time long gone by . Then it occurred to [him]46-tom that the great adventure itself must be a dream ! There was one very strong argument in favor of this idea — namely , that the quantity of coin [he]46-tom had seen was too vast to be real . [He]46-tom had never seen as much as fifty dollars in one mass before , and [he]46-tom was like [all boys of [his]46-tom age and station in life]2778-all boys of his age and station in life , in that [he]46-tom imagined that all references to “[45-huck] hundreds ” and “[1670-he] thousands ” were mere fanciful forms of speech , and that no such sums really existed in [the world]328-the world . [He]46-tom never had supposed for a moment that so large a sum as a hundred dollars was to be found in actual money in [any one]2780-any one ’s possession . If [his]46-tom notions of hidden treasure had been analyzed , they would have been found to consist of a handful of real dimes and a bushel of vague , splendid , ungraspable dollars . But the incidents of [his]46-tom adventure grew sensibly sharper and clearer under the attrition of thinking them over , and so [he]46-tom presently found [himself]46-tom leaning to the impression that the thing might not have been a dream , after all . This uncertainty must be swept away . [He]46-tom would snatch a hurried breakfast and go and find [Huck]45-huck . [Huck]45-huck was sitting on the gunwale of [a flatboat]2781-a flatboat , listlessly dangling [his]45-huck feet in the water and looking very melancholy . [Tom]46-tom concluded to let [Huck]45-huck lead up to the subject . If [he]46-tom did not do it , then the adventure would be proved to have been only a dream . “[45-huck] Hello , [Huck]45-huck ! ” “[45-huck] Hello , [yourself]45-huck . ” Silence , for a minute . “[45-huck] [Tom]46-tom , if [we]1672-we ’d ’ a ’ left the blame tools at the dead tree , [we]1672-we ’d ’ a ’ got the money . Oh , ai n’t it awful ! ” “[45-huck] ’ Tain’t a dream , then , ’ tain’t a dream ! Somehow [I]0-i most wish it was . Dog’d if [I]0-i do n’t , [Huck]45-huck . ” “[45-huck] What ai n’t a dream ? ” “[45-huck] Oh , that thing yesterday . [I]0-i been half thinking it was . ” “[0-i] Dream ! If [them]1673-them stairs had n’t broke down [you]45-huck ’d ’ a ’ seen how much dream it was ! [I]0-i ’ve had dreams enough all night — with that patch - eyed Spanish devil going for [me]0-i all through ’em — rot [him]45-huck ! ” “[45-huck] No , not rot [him]45-huck . _ Find _ [him]45-huck ! Track the money ! ” “[46-tom] [Tom]46-tom , [we]1672-we ’ll never find [him]45-huck . [A feller]2286-a feller do n’t have only one chance for such a pile — and that one ’s lost . [I]0-i ’d feel mighty shaky if [I]0-i was to see [him]45-huck , anyway . ” “[45-huck] Well , so’d [I]0-i ; but [I]0-i ’d like to see [him]45-huck , anyway — and track [him]45-huck out — to [his]45-huck Number Two . ” “[45-huck] Number Two — yes , that ’s it . [I]0-i been thinking ’bout that . But [I]0-i ca n’t make nothing out of it . What do [you]46-tom reckon it is ? ” “[0-i] [I]0-i dono . It ’s too deep . Say , [Huck]45-huck — maybe it ’s the number of [a house]678-a house ! ” “[45-huck] Goody ! ... No , [Tom]46-tom , that ai n’t it . If it is , it ai n’t in [this one - horse town]1676-this one - horse town . [They]1677-they ai n’t no numbers here . ” “[1677-they] Well , that ’s so . Lemme think a minute . Here — it ’s the number of [a room]1678-a room — in [a tavern]1679-a tavern , [you]46-tom know ! ” “[46-tom] Oh , that ’s the trick ! [They]1677-they ai n’t only [two taverns]1680-two taverns . [We]1681-we can find out quick . ” “[46-tom] [You]46-tom stay here , [Huck]45-huck , till [I]0-i come . ” [Tom]46-tom was off at once . [He]46-tom did not care to have [Huck]45-huck ’s company in [public places]2782-public places . [He]46-tom was gone half an hour . [He]46-tom found that in [the best tavern , No . 2]2783-the best tavern , no . 2 had long been occupied by [a young lawyer]2784-a young lawyer , and was still so occupied . In [the less ostentatious house]2785-the less ostentatious house , [No . 2]2786-no . 2 was a mystery . [[The tavern - keeper]2787-the tavern - keeper ’s young son]2788-the tavern - keeper ’s young son said it was kept locked all the time , and [he]2788-the tavern - keeper ’s young son never saw [anybody]203-anybody go into [it]2785-the less ostentatious house or come out of [it]2785-the less ostentatious house except at night ; [he]2788-the tavern - keeper ’s young son did not know any particular reason for this state of things ; had had some little curiosity , but it was rather feeble ; had made the most of the mystery by entertaining [himself]2788-the tavern - keeper ’s young son with the idea that [that room]2790-that room was “[0-i] ha’nted ” ; had noticed that there was a light in there the night before . “[0-i] That ’s what [I]0-i ’ve found out , [Huck]45-huck . [I]0-i reckon that ’s [the very No . 2 [we]1683-we ’re after]1682-the very no . 2 we ’re after . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i reckon it is , [Tom]46-tom . Now what [you]46-tom going to do ? ” “[46-tom] Lemme think . ” [Tom]46-tom thought a long time . Then [he]46-tom said : “[46-tom] [I]0-i ’ll tell [you]46-tom . [The back door of [that No . 2]1685-that no . 2]1684-the back door of that no . 2 is the door that comes out into [that little close alley between [the tavern]1687-the tavern and the old rattle trap of [a brick store]1688-a brick store]1686-that little close alley between the tavern and the old rattle trap of a brick store . Now [you]46-tom get hold of all the doorkeys [you]46-tom can find , and [I]0-i ’ll nip all of [[auntie]2133-auntie ’s]1690-auntie ’s , and the first dark night [we]1683-we ’ll go [there]2038-there and try ’em . And mind [you]46-tom , keep a lookout for [Injun Joe]100-injun joe , because [he]100-injun joe said [he]100-injun joe was going to drop into [town]526-town and spy around once more for a chance to get [his]100-injun joe revenge . If [you]46-tom see [him]100-injun joe , [you]46-tom just follow [him]100-injun joe ; and if [he]100-injun joe do n’t go to [that No . 2]1685-that no . 2 , that ai n’t [the place]791-the place . ” “[95-lordy] [Lordy]95-lordy , [I]0-i do n’t want to foller [him]100-injun joe by [myself]0-i ! ” “[95-lordy] Why , it ’ll be night , sure . [He]100-injun joe might n’t ever see [you]46-tom — and if [he]100-injun joe did , maybe [he]100-injun joe ’d never think anything . ” “[100-injun joe] Well , if it ’s pretty dark [I]0-i reckon [I]0-i ’ll track [him]100-injun joe . [I]0-i dono — [I]0-i dono . [I]0-i ’ll try . ” “[0-i] [You]46-tom bet [I]0-i ’ll follow [him]100-injun joe , if it ’s dark , [Huck]45-huck . Why , [he]100-injun joe might ’ a ’ found out [he]100-injun joe could n’t get [his]100-injun joe revenge , and be going right after that money . ” “[100-injun joe] It ’s so , [Tom]46-tom , it ’s so . [I]0-i ’ll foller [him]100-injun joe ; [I]0-i will , by [jingoes]2289-jingoes ! ” “[2289-jingoes] Now [you]45-huck ’re _ talking _ ! Do n’t [you]45-huck ever weaken , [Huck]45-huck , and [I]0-i wo n’t . ” CHAPTER XXVIII That night [Tom]46-tom and [Huck]45-huck were ready for [their]2791-their adventure . [They]2791-their hung about [the neighborhood of [the tavern]1687-the tavern]2792-the neighborhood of the tavern until after nine , one watching [the alley]2794-the alley at a distance and the other the tavern door . [Nobody]647-nobody entered [the alley]2794-the alley or left [it]2794-the alley ; [nobody resembling the Spaniard]2797-nobody resembling the spaniard entered or left [the tavern]1687-the tavern door . The night promised to be a fair one ; so [Tom]46-tom went [home]197-home with the understanding that if a considerable degree of darkness came on , [Huck]45-huck was to come and “[0-i] maow , ” whereupon [he]45-huck would slip out and try the keys . But the night remained clear , and [Huck]45-huck closed [his]45-huck watch and retired to bed in [an empty sugar hogshead]2800-an empty sugar hogshead about twelve . Tuesday [the boys]2054-the boys had the same ill luck . Also Wednesday . But Thursday night promised better . [Tom]46-tom slipped out in good season with [[his]46-tom aunt]196-his aunt ’s old tin lantern , and a large towel to blindfold it with . [He]46-tom hid the lantern in [Huck]45-huck ’s sugar hogshead and the watch began . An hour before midnight [the tavern]1687-the tavern closed up and [its]1687-the tavern lights ( the only ones thereabouts ) were put out . [No Spaniard]2804-no spaniard had been seen . [Nobody]647-nobody had entered or left [the alley]2794-the alley . Everything was auspicious . The blackness of darkness reigned , the perfect stillness was interrupted only by occasional mutterings of distant thunder . [Tom]46-tom got [his]46-tom lantern , lit it in the hogshead , wrapped it closely in the towel , and [the two adventurers]2807-the two adventurers crept in the gloom toward [the tavern]1687-the tavern . [Huck]45-huck stood sentry and [Tom]46-tom felt [his]46-tom way into [the alley]2794-the alley . Then there was a season of waiting anxiety that weighed upon [Huck]45-huck ’s spirits like a mountain . [He]46-tom began to wish [he]46-tom could see a flash from the lantern — it would frighten [him]46-tom , but it would at least tell [him]46-tom that [Tom]46-tom was alive yet . It seemed hours since [Tom]46-tom had disappeared . Surely [he]46-tom must have fainted ; maybe [he]46-tom was dead ; maybe [his]46-tom heart had burst under terror and excitement . In [his]46-tom uneasiness [Huck]45-huck found [himself]46-tom drawing closer and closer to [the alley]2794-the alley ; fearing all sorts of dreadful things , and momentarily expecting some catastrophe to happen that would take away [his]46-tom breath . There was not much to take away , for [he]46-tom seemed only able to inhale it by thimblefuls , and [his]46-tom heart would soon wear itself out , the way it was beating . Suddenly there was a flash of light and [Tom]46-tom came tearing by [him]46-tom : “[0-i] Run ! ” said [he]46-tom ; “[1696-your] run , for [your]1696-your life ! ” [He]46-tom need n’t have repeated it ; once was enough ; [Huck]45-huck was making thirty or forty miles an hour before the repetition was uttered . [The boys]2054-the boys never stopped till [they]2054-the boys reached [the shed of [a deserted slaughter - house]2813-a deserted slaughter - house at [the lower end of [the village]206-the village]2814-the lower end of the village]2812-the shed of a deserted slaughter - house at the lower end of the village . Just as [they]2054-the boys got within [its]2812-the shed of a deserted slaughter - house at the lower end of the village shelter the storm burst and the rain poured down . As soon as [Tom]46-tom got [his]46-tom breath [he]46-tom said : “[45-huck] [Huck]45-huck , it was awful ! [I]0-i tried two of the keys , just as soft as [I]0-i could ; but they seemed to make such a power of racket that [I]0-i could n’t hardly get [my]0-i breath [I]0-i was so scared . [They]1697-they would n’t turn in the lock , either . Well , without noticing what [I]0-i was doing , [I]0-i took hold of the knob , and open comes the door ! It warn’t locked ! [I]0-i hopped in , and shook off the towel , and , _ Great [Caesar]156-caesar ’s Ghost ! _ ” “[0-i] What!—what’d [you]45-huck see , [Tom]46-tom ? ” “[45-huck] [Huck]45-huck , [I]0-i most stepped onto Injun [Joe]100-injun joe ’s hand ! ” “[0-i] No ! ” “[0-i] Yes ! [He]100-injun joe was lying there , sound asleep on the floor , with [his]100-injun joe old patch on [his]100-injun joe eye and [his]100-injun joe arms spread out . ” “[100-injun joe] [Lordy]95-lordy , what did [you]45-huck do ? Did [he]100-injun joe wake up ? ” “[100-injun joe] No , never budged . Drunk , [I]0-i reckon . [I]0-i just grabbed that towel and started ! ” “[0-i] [I]0-i ’d never ’ a ’ thought of the towel , [I]0-i bet ! ” “[0-i] Well , [I]0-i would . [[My]0-i aunt]1698-my aunt would make [me]0-i mighty sick if [I]0-i lost it . ” “[46-tom] Say , [Tom]46-tom , did [you]46-tom see that box ? ” “[45-huck] [Huck]45-huck , [I]0-i did n’t wait to look around . [I]0-i did n’t see the box , [I]0-i did n’t see the cross . [I]0-i did n’t see anything but a bottle and a tin cup on the floor by [Injun Joe]100-injun joe ; yes , [I]0-i saw two barrels and lots more bottles in [the room]190-the room . Do n’t [you]45-huck see , now , what ’s the matter with [that ha’nted room]1700-that ha’nted room ? ” “[45-huck] How ? ” “[45-huck] Why , it ’s ha’nted with whiskey ! Maybe _ all _ [the Temperance Taverns]1701-the temperance taverns have got [a ha’nted room]1702-a ha’nted room , hey , [Huck]45-huck ? ” “[45-huck] Well , [I]0-i reckon maybe that ’s so . Who ’d ’ a ’ thought such a thing ? But say , [Tom]46-tom , now ’s a mighty good time to get that box , if [Injun Joe]100-injun joe ’s drunk . ” “[100-injun joe] It is , that ! [You]46-tom try it ! ” [Huck]45-huck shuddered . “[46-tom] Well , no — [I]0-i reckon not . ” “[0-i] And [I]0-i reckon not , [Huck]45-huck . Only one bottle alongside of Injun [Joe]100-injun joe ai n’t enough . If there ’d been three , [he]100-injun joe ’d be drunk enough and [I]0-i ’d do it . ” There was a long pause for reflection , and then [Tom]46-tom said : “[0-i] Lookyhere , [Huck]45-huck , less not try that thing any more till [we]1703-we know [Injun Joe]100-injun joe ’s not in [there]2038-there . It ’s too scary . Now , if [we]1703-we watch every night , [we]1703-we ’ll be dead sure to see [him]100-injun joe go out , some time or other , and then [we]1703-we ’ll snatch that box quicker’n lightning . ” “[1703-we] Well , [I]0-i ’m agreed . [I]0-i ’ll watch the whole night long , and [I]0-i ’ll do it every night , too , if [you]46-tom ’ll do the other part of the job . ” “[46-tom] All right , [I]0-i will . All [you]46-tom got to do is to trot up [Hooper Street]35-hooper street a block and maow — and if [I]0-i ’m asleep , [you]46-tom throw some gravel at the window and that ’ll fetch [me]0-i . ” “[46-tom] Agreed , and good as wheat ! ” “[46-tom] Now , [Huck]45-huck , the storm ’s over , and [I]0-i ’ll go [home]197-home . It ’ll begin to be daylight in a couple of hours . [You]46-tom go back and watch that long , will [you]46-tom ? ” “[0-i] [I]0-i said [I]0-i would , [Tom]46-tom , and [I]0-i will . [I]0-i ’ll ha’nt [that tavern]1706-that tavern every night for a year ! [I]0-i ’ll sleep all day and [I]0-i ’ll stand watch all night . ” “[0-i] That ’s all right . Now , where [you]46-tom going to sleep ? ” “[57-ben] In [[Ben Rogers]57-ben ’ hayloft]1707-ben rogers ’ hayloft . [He]57-ben lets [me]0-i , and so does [[his]57-ben pap ’s nigger man]1708-his pap ’s nigger man , [Uncle Jake]157-uncle jake . [I]0-i tote water for [Uncle Jake]157-uncle jake whenever [he]157-uncle jake wants [me]0-i to , and any time [I]0-i ask [him]157-uncle jake [he]157-uncle jake gives [me]0-i a little something to eat if [he]157-uncle jake can spare it . That ’s [a mighty good nigger]1709-a mighty good nigger , [Tom]46-tom . [He]57-ben likes [me]0-i , becuz [I]0-i do n’t ever act as if [I]0-i was above [him]57-ben . Sometime [I]0-i ’ve set right down and eat _ with _ [him]57-ben . But [you]46-tom need n’t tell that . [A body]2452-a body ’s got to do things when [he]2452-a body ’s awful hungry [he]2452-a body would n’t want to do as a steady thing . ” “[2452-a body] Well , if [I]0-i do n’t want [you]46-tom in the daytime , [I]0-i ’ll let [you]46-tom sleep . [I]0-i wo n’t come bothering around . Any time [you]46-tom see something ’s up , in the night , just skip right around and maow . ” CHAPTER XXIX The first thing [Tom]46-tom heard on Friday morning was a glad piece of news — [[Judge Thatcher]158-judge thatcher ’s family]2816-judge thatcher ’s family had come back to [town]526-town the night before . [Both Injun Joe]100-injun joe and [the treasure]2818-the treasure sunk into secondary importance for a moment , and [Becky]86-becky took the chief place in [the boy]2044-the boy ’s interest . [He]46-tom saw [her]86-becky and [they]2820-they had an exhausting good time playing “[2452-a body] hispy ” and “[2452-a body] gully - keeper ” with [a crowd of [[their]2820-they schoolmates]2822-their schoolmates]2821-a crowd of their schoolmates . The day was completed and crowned in a peculiarly satisfactory way : [Becky]86-becky teased [[her]86-becky mother]2823-her mother to appoint the next day for the long - promised and long - delayed picnic , and [she]2823-her mother consented . [The child]2048-the child ’s delight was boundless ; and [Tom]46-tom ’s not more moderate . The invitations were sent out before sunset , and straightway [the young folks of [the village]206-the village]2825-the young folks of the village were thrown into a fever of preparation and pleasurable anticipation . [Tom]46-tom ’s excitement enabled [him]46-tom to keep awake until a pretty late hour , and [he]46-tom had good hopes of hearing [Huck]45-huck ’s “[2452-a body] maow , ” and of having [his]46-tom treasure to astonish [Becky]86-becky and [the picnickers]2827-the picnickers with , next day ; but [he]46-tom was disappointed . No signal came that night . Morning came , eventually , and by ten or eleven o’clock [a giddy and rollicking company]2828-a giddy and rollicking company were gathered at [Judge Thatcher ’s]158-judge thatcher , and everything was ready for a start . It was not the custom for [elderly people]2829-elderly people to mar the picnics with [their]2829-elderly people presence . [The children]383-the children were considered safe enough under the wings of [a few young ladies of eighteen and a few young gentlemen of twenty - three or thereabouts]2831-a few young ladies of eighteen and a few young gentlemen of twenty - three or thereabouts . [The old steam ferry - boat]2832-the old steam ferry - boat was chartered for the occasion ; presently [the gay throng]2833-the gay throng filed up [the main street]2834-the main street laden with provision - baskets . [Sid]51-sid was sick and had to miss the fun ; [Mary]47-aunt polly remained at [home]197-home to entertain [him]51-sid . The last thing [Mrs. Thatcher]159-mrs. thatcher said to [Becky]86-becky , was : “[2452-a body] [You]1711-you ’ll not get back till late . Perhaps [you]1711-you ’d better stay all night with [some of [the girls that live near [the ferry - landing]1714-the ferry - landing]1713-the girls that live near the ferry - landing]1712-some of the girls that live near the ferry - landing , [child]2139-child . ” “[1712-some of the girls that live near the ferry - landing] Then [I]0-i ’ll stay with [Susy Harper]128-susy harper , [mamma]1716-mamma . ” “[128-susy harper] Very well . And mind and behave [yourself]1711-you and do n’t be any trouble . ” Presently , as [they]1718-we tripped along , [Tom]46-tom said to [Becky]86-becky : “[1717-i’ll] Say — [I’ll]1717-i’ll tell [you]1711-you what [we]1718-we ’ll do . ’ Stead of going to [Joe Harper]62-joe ’s [we]1718-we ’ll climb right up [the hill]2700-the hill and stop at [the Widow Douglas ’]71-the widow douglas . [She]1720-she ’ll have ice - cream ! [She]1720-she has it most every day — dead loads of it . And [she]1720-she ’ll be awful glad to have [us]1718-we . ” “[1720-she] Oh , that will be fun ! ” Then [Becky]86-becky reflected a moment and said : “[1720-she] But what will [mamma]1716-mamma say ? ” “[1716-mamma] How ’ll [she]1720-she ever know ? ” [The girl]334-the girl turned the idea over in [her]334-the girl mind , and said reluctantly : “[1720-she] [I]0-i reckon it ’s wrong — but — ” “[0-i] But shucks ! [[Your]1711-you mother]2405-your mother wo n’t know , and so what ’s the harm ? All [she]2405-your mother wants is that [you]1711-you ’ll be safe ; and [I]0-i bet [you]1711-you [she]2405-your mother ’d ’ a ’ said go there if [she]2405-your mother ’d ’ a ’ thought of it . [I]0-i know [she]2405-your mother would ! ” [The Widow Douglas]71-the widow douglas ’ splendid hospitality was a tempting bait . [It]2837-it and [Tom]46-tom ’s persuasions presently carried the day . So it was decided to say nothing to [anybody]203-anybody about the night ’s programme . Presently it occurred to [Tom]46-tom that maybe [Huck]45-huck might come this very night and give the signal . The thought took a deal of the spirit out of [his]46-tom anticipations . Still [he]46-tom could not bear to give up the fun at [Widow Douglas]71-the widow douglas ’ . And why should [he]46-tom give it up , [he]46-tom reasoned — the signal did not come the night before , so why should it be any more likely to come tonight ? The sure fun of the evening outweighed the uncertain treasure ; and , [boy]2839-boy - like , [he]46-tom determined to yield to the stronger inclination and not allow [himself]46-tom to think of the box of money another time that day . Three miles below [town]526-town [the ferryboat]1103-the ferryboat stopped at [the mouth of [a woody hollow]2843-a woody hollow]2842-the mouth of a woody hollow and tied up . [The crowd]506-the crowd swarmed ashore and soon [the forest distances]2845-the forest distances and [craggy heights]2846-craggy heights echoed far and near with shoutings and laughter . All the different ways of getting hot and tired were gone through with , and by - and - by [the rovers]2847-the rovers straggled back to [camp]1075-camp fortified with responsible appetites , and then the destruction of the good things began . After the feast there was a refreshing season of rest and chat in the shade of spreading oaks . [By - and - by somebody]2849-by - and - by somebody shouted : “[2405-your mother] Who ’s ready for [the cave]1723-the cave ? ” [Everybody]490-everybody was . Bundles of candles were procured , and straightway there was a general scamper up [the hill]2700-the hill . [The mouth of [the cave]1723-the cave]2852-the mouth of the cave was up [the hillside]2854-the hillside — an opening shaped like a letter A. [Its]2852-the mouth of the cave massive oaken door stood unbarred . Within was [a small chamber , chilly as [an icehouse]2856-an icehouse , and walled by Nature with solid limestone that was dewy with a cold sweat]2855-a small chamber , chilly as an icehouse , and walled by nature with solid limestone that was dewy with a cold sweat . It was romantic and mysterious to stand here in the deep gloom and look out upon [the green valley]2857-the green valley shining in the sun . But the impressiveness of the situation quickly wore off , and the romping began again . The moment a candle was lighted there was a general rush upon [the owner of it]805-the owner of it ; a struggle and a gallant defence followed , but the candle was soon knocked down or blown out , and then there was a glad clamor of laughter and a new chase . But all things have an end . By - and - by [the procession]883-the procession went filing down [the steep descent of the main avenue]2860-the steep descent of the main avenue , the flickering rank of lights dimly revealing the lofty walls of rock almost to their point of junction sixty feet overhead . [This main avenue]2861-this main avenue was not more than eight or ten feet wide . Every few steps other lofty and still narrower crevices branched from [it]2861-this main avenue on either hand — for [[McDougal]160-mcdougal ’s cave]2862-mcdougal ’s cave was but [a vast labyrinth of crooked aisles that ran into each other and out again and led nowhere]2863-a vast labyrinth of crooked aisles that ran into each other and out again and led nowhere . It was said that [one]934-one might wander days and nights together through [its]2862-mcdougal ’s cave intricate tangle of rifts and chasms , and never find the end of [the cave]1723-the cave ; and that [he]934-one might go down , and down , and still down , into [the earth]2866-the earth , and it was just the same — [labyrinth under labyrinth]2867-labyrinth under labyrinth , and no end to any of [them]2868-them . [No man]2228-no man “[2405-your mother] knew ” [the cave]1723-the cave . That was an impossible thing . [Most of [the young men]425-the young men]2871-most of the young men knew a portion of [it]1723-the cave , and it was not customary to venture much beyond this known portion . [Tom Sawyer]46-tom knew as much of [the cave]1723-the cave as [any one]2780-any one . [The procession]883-the procession moved along [the main avenue]2876-the main avenue some three - quarters of a mile , and then [groups]2877-groups and [couples]2878-couples began to slip aside into branch avenues , fly along [the dismal corridors]2879-the dismal corridors , and take [each other]227-each other by surprise at points where [the corridors]2881-the corridors joined again . [Parties]2882-parties were able to elude [each other]227-each other for the space of half an hour without going beyond [the “[2405-your mother] known ” ground]2884-the “ known ” ground . By - and - by , [one group]2885-one group after another came straggling back to the mouth of [the cave]1723-the cave , panting , hilarious , smeared from head to foot with tallow drippings , daubed with clay , and entirely delighted with the success of the day . Then [they]2882-parties were astonished to find that [they]2882-parties had been taking no note of time and that night was about at hand . The clanging bell had been calling for half an hour . However , this sort of close to the day ’s adventures was romantic and therefore satisfactory . When [the ferryboat]1103-the ferryboat with [[her]1103-the ferryboat wild freight]2888-her wild freight pushed into [the stream]355-the stream , [nobody]647-nobody cared sixpence for the wasted time but [the captain of [the craft]2892-the craft]2891-the captain of the craft . [Huck]45-huck was already upon [his]45-huck watch when [the ferryboat]1103-the ferryboat ’s lights went glinting past [the wharf]2894-the wharf . [He]45-huck heard no noise on board , for [the young people]2895-the young people were as subdued and still as [people usually are who are nearly tired to death]2896-people usually are who are nearly tired to death . [He]45-huck wondered what [boat]272-boat [it]272-boat was , and why [she]1103-the ferryboat did not stop at [the wharf]2894-the wharf — and then [he]45-huck dropped [her]1103-the ferryboat out of [his]45-huck mind and put [his]45-huck attention upon [his]45-huck business . The night was growing cloudy and dark . Ten o’clock came , and the noise of [vehicles]2899-vehicles ceased , scattered lights began to wink out , [all straggling foot - passengers]2900-all straggling foot - passengers disappeared , [the village]206-the village betook itself to [its]206-the village slumbers and left [the small watcher]2902-the small watcher alone with the silence and the ghosts . Eleven o’clock came , and [the tavern]1687-the tavern lights were put out ; darkness everywhere , now . [Huck]45-huck waited what seemed a weary long time , but nothing happened . [His]45-huck faith was weakening . Was there any use ? Was there really any use ? Why not give it up and turn in ? A noise fell upon [his]45-huck ear . [He]45-huck was all attention in an instant . [The alley]2794-the alley door closed softly . [He]45-huck sprang to the corner of [the brick store]2905-the brick store . The next moment [two men]2724-two men brushed by [him]45-huck , and one seemed to have something under [his]45-huck arm . It must be that box ! So [they]2724-two men were going to remove the treasure . Why call [Tom]46-tom now ? It would be absurd — [the men]810-the men would get away with the box and never be found again . No , [he]45-huck would stick to [their]810-the men wake and follow [them]810-the men ; [he]45-huck would trust to the darkness for security from discovery . So communing with [himself]45-huck , [Huck]45-huck stepped out and glided along behind [the men]810-the men , cat - like , with bare feet , allowing [them]810-the men to keep just far enough ahead not to be invisible . [They]810-the men moved up [the river street]2909-the river street three blocks , then turned to the left up a crossstreet . [They]810-the men went straight ahead , then , until [they]810-the men came to the path that led up [Cardiff Hill]4-cardiff hill ; this [they]810-the men took . [They]810-the men passed by [[the old Welshman]2910-the old welshman ’s house]2911-the old welshman ’s house , halfway up [the hill]2700-the hill , without hesitating , and still climbed upward . Good , thought [Huck]45-huck , [they]810-the men will bury it in [the old quarry]2913-the old quarry . But [they]810-the men never stopped at [the quarry]2914-the quarry . [They]810-the men passed on , up [the summit]2915-the summit . [They]810-the men plunged into [the narrow path between the tall sumach bushes]2916-the narrow path between the tall sumach bushes , and were at once hidden in the gloom . [Huck]45-huck closed up and shortened [his]45-huck distance , now , for [they]810-the men would never be able to see [him]45-huck . [He]45-huck trotted along awhile ; then slackened [his]45-huck pace , fearing [he]45-huck was gaining too fast ; moved on a piece , then stopped altogether ; listened ; no sound ; none , save that [he]45-huck seemed to hear the beating of [his]45-huck own heart . The hooting of an owl came over [the hill]2700-the hill — ominous sound ! But no footsteps . Heavens , was everything lost ! [He]45-huck was about to spring with winged feet , when [a man]208-a man cleared [his]208-a man throat not four feet from [him]45-huck ! [Huck]45-huck ’s heart shot into [his]45-huck throat , but [he]45-huck swallowed it again ; and then [he]45-huck stood there shaking as if a dozen agues had taken charge of [him]45-huck at once , and so weak that [he]45-huck thought [he]45-huck must surely fall to the ground . [He]45-huck knew where [he]45-huck was . [He]45-huck knew [he]45-huck was within five steps of the stile leading into [[Widow Douglas]71-the widow douglas ’ grounds]2919-widow douglas ’ grounds . Very well , [he]45-huck thought , let [them]2920-them bury it there ; it wo n’t be hard to find . Now there was a voice — a very low voice — Injun [Joe]62-joe ’s : “[1724-her] Damn [her]1724-her , maybe [she]1724-her ’s got [company]412-company — there ’s lights , late as it is . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i ca n’t see any . ” This was [that stranger]2921-that stranger ’s voice — [the stranger of [the haunted house]2705-the haunted house]2922-the stranger of the haunted house . A deadly chill went to [Huck]45-huck ’s heart — this , then , was the “[0-i] revenge ” job ! [His]45-huck thought was , to fly . Then [he]45-huck remembered that [the Widow Douglas]71-the widow douglas had been kind to [him]45-huck more than once , and maybe [these men]2924-these men were going to murder [her]1724-her . [He]45-huck wished [he]45-huck dared venture to warn [her]1724-her ; but [he]45-huck knew [he]45-huck did n’t dare — [they]2924-these men might come and catch [him]45-huck . [He]45-huck thought all this and more in the moment that elapsed between [the stranger]240-the stranger ’s remark and [Injun Joe]100-injun joe ’s next — which was — “[0-i] Because the bush is in [your]1726-you way . Now — this way — now [you]1726-you see , do n’t [you]1726-you ? ” “[1726-you] Yes . Well , there _ is _ company there , [I]0-i reckon . Better give it up . ” “[0-i] Give it up , and [I]0-i just leaving [this country]1499-this country forever ! Give it up and maybe never have another chance . [I]0-i tell [you]1726-you again , as [I]0-i ’ve told [you]1726-you before , [I]0-i do n’t care for [her]1728-her swag — [you]1726-you may have it . But [[her]1728-her husband]1729-her husband was rough on [me]0-i — many times [he]1729-her husband was rough on [me]0-i — and mainly [he]1729-her husband was [the justice of the peace that jugged [me]0-i for [a vagrant]2254-a vagrant]1730-the justice of the peace that jugged me for a vagrant . And that ai n’t all . It ai n’t a millionth part of it ! [He]1729-her husband had [me]0-i _ horsewhipped_!—horsewhipped in front of [the jail]917-the jail , like [a nigger!—with all [the town]519-the town looking on]1733-a nigger!—with all the town looking on ! _ Horsewhipped_!—do [you]1726-you understand ? [He]1729-her husband took advantage of [me]0-i and died . But [I]0-i ’ll take it out of _ [her]1728-her _ . ” “[0-i] Oh , do n’t kill [her]1728-her ! Do n’t do that ! ” “[0-i] Kill ? Who said anything about killing ? [I]0-i would kill _ [him]1729-her husband _ if [he]1729-her husband was [here]551-here ; but not [her]1728-her . When [you]1726-you want to get revenge on [a woman]1736-a woman [you]1726-you do n’t kill [her]1728-her — bosh ! [you]1726-you go for [her]1728-her looks . [You]1726-you slit [her]1728-her nostrils — [you]1726-you notch [her]1728-her ears like a sow ! ” “[1726-you] By [God]65-god , that ’s — ” “[1726-you] Keep [your]1726-you opinion to [yourself]1726-you ! It will be safest for [you]1726-you . [I]0-i ’ll tie [her]1728-her to the bed . If [she]1728-her bleeds to death , is that [my]0-i fault ? [I]0-i ’ll not cry , if [she]1728-her does . [[My]0-i friend]1737-my friend , [you]1726-you ’ll help [me]0-i in this thing — for _ [my]0-i _ sake — that ’s why [you]1726-you ’re here — [I]0-i might n’t be able alone . If [you]1726-you flinch , [I]0-i ’ll kill [you]1726-you . Do [you]1726-you understand that ? And if [I]0-i have to kill [you]1726-you , [I]0-i ’ll kill [her]1728-her — and then [I]0-i reckon [nobody’ll]2504-nobody’ll ever know much about [who done this business]1739-who done this business . ” “[0-i] Well , if it ’s got to be done , let ’s get at it . The quicker the better — [I’m]0-i all in a shiver . ” “[0-i] Do it _ now _ ? And [company]412-company [there]2038-there ? Look here — [I’ll]0-i get suspicious of [you]1726-you , first thing [you]1726-you know . No — we’ll wait till the lights are out — there ’s no hurry . ” [Huck]45-huck felt that a silence was going to ensue — a thing still more awful than any amount of murderous talk ; so [he]45-huck held [his]45-huck breath and stepped gingerly back ; planted [his]45-huck foot carefully and firmly , after balancing , one - legged , in a precarious way and almost toppling over , first on one side and then on the other . [He]45-huck took another step back , with the same elaboration and the same risks ; then another and another , and — a twig snapped under [his]45-huck foot ! [His]45-huck breath stopped and [he]45-huck listened . There was no sound — the stillness was perfect . [His]45-huck gratitude was measureless . Now [he]45-huck turned in [his]45-huck tracks , between the walls of sumach bushes — turned [himself]45-huck as carefully as if [he]45-huck were [a ship]1174-a ship — and then stepped quickly but cautiously along . When [he]45-huck emerged at [the quarry]2914-the quarry [he]45-huck felt secure , and so [he]45-huck picked up [his]45-huck nimble heels and flew . Down , down [he]45-huck sped , till [he]45-huck reached [the Welshman]2928-the welshman ’s . [He]45-huck banged at the door , and presently the heads of [the old man]2929-the old man and [[his]2929-the old man two stalwart sons]2930-his two stalwart sons were thrust from windows . “[45-huck] What ’s the row there ? Who ’s banging ? What do [you]1742-you want ? ” “[1742-you] Let [me]0-i in — quick ! [I]0-i ’ll tell everything . ” “[0-i] Why , who are [you]1742-you ? ” “[45-huck] [Huckleberry Finn]45-huck — quick , let [me]0-i in ! ” “[45-huck] [Huckleberry Finn]45-huck , indeed ! It ai n’t a name to open many doors , [I]0-i judge ! But let [him]45-huck in , [lads]1743-lads , and let ’s see what ’s the trouble . ” “[1578-the widow] Please do n’t ever tell [I]0-i told [you]1742-you , ” were [Huck]45-huck ’s first words when [he]45-huck got in . “[0-i] Please don’t — [I’d]0-i be killed , sure — but [the widow]1578-the widow ’s been good friends to [me]0-i sometimes , and [I]0-i want to tell — [I]0-i _ will _ tell if [you]1742-you ’ll promise [you]1742-you wo n’t ever say it was [me]0-i . ” “[0-i] By [George]161-george , [he]45-huck _ has _ got something to tell , or [he]45-huck would n’t act so ! ” exclaimed [the old man]2929-the old man ; “[45-huck] out with it and [nobody]647-nobody here’ll ever tell , [lad]1644-lad . ” Three minutes later [the old man]2929-the old man and [[his]2929-the old man sons]2933-his sons , well armed , were up [the hill]2700-the hill , and just entering [the sumach path]2935-the sumach path on tiptoe , [their]2933-his sons weapons in [their]2933-his sons hands . [Huck]45-huck accompanied [them]2933-his sons no further . [He]45-huck hid behind a great bowlder and fell to listening . There was a lagging , anxious silence , and then all of a sudden there was an explosion of firearms and a cry . [Huck]45-huck waited for no particulars . [He]45-huck sprang away and sped down [the hill]2700-the hill as fast as [his]45-huck legs could carry [him]45-huck . CHAPTER XXX As the earliest suspicion of dawn appeared on Sunday morning , [Huck]45-huck came groping up [the hill]2700-the hill and rapped gently at [the old Welshman]2910-the old welshman ’s door . [The inmates]2939-the inmates were asleep , but it was a sleep that was set on a hair - trigger , on account of the exciting episode of the night . A call came from a window : “[647-nobody] Who ’s there ! ” [Huck]45-huck ’s scared voice answered in a low tone : “[647-nobody] Please let [me]0-i in ! It ’s only [Huck Finn]45-huck ! ” “[45-huck] It ’s a name that can open this door night or day , lad!—and welcome ! ” These were strange words to [the vagabond boy]2940-the vagabond boy ’s ears , and the pleasantest [he]45-huck had ever heard . [He]45-huck could not recollect that the closing word had ever been applied in [his]45-huck case before . The door was quickly unlocked , and [he]45-huck entered . [Huck]45-huck was given a seat and [the old man]2929-the old man and [[his]2929-the old man brace of tall sons]2942-his brace of tall sons speedily dressed [themselves]1748-themselves . “[45-huck] Now , [[my]0-i boy]1534-my boy , [I]0-i hope [you]1534-my boy ’re good and hungry , because breakfast will be ready as soon as the sun ’s up , and [we]1748-themselves ’ll have a piping hot one , too — make [yourself]1534-my boy easy about that ! [I]0-i and [the boys]2054-the boys hoped [you]1534-my boy ’d turn up and stop here last night . ” “[2054-the boys] [I]0-i was awful scared , ” said [Huck]45-huck , “[0-i] and [I]0-i run . [I]0-i took out when the pistols went off , and [I]0-i did n’t stop for three mile . [I]0-i ’ve come now becuz [I]0-i wanted to know about it , [you]1534-my boy know ; and [I]0-i come before daylight becuz [I]0-i did n’t want to run across [them]2054-the boys devils , even if [they]2054-the boys was dead . ” “[0-i] Well , [poor chap]1750-poor chap , [you]1534-my boy do look as if [you]1534-my boy ’d had a hard night of it — but there ’s a bed here for [you]1534-my boy when [you]1534-my boy ’ve had [your]1534-my boy breakfast . No , [they]2054-the boys ai n’t dead , [lad]1644-lad — [we]1752-we are sorry enough for that . [You]1534-my boy see [we]1752-we knew right where to put [our]1752-we hands on [them]2054-the boys , by [your]1534-my boy description ; so [we]1752-we crept along on tiptoe till [we]1752-we got within fifteen feet of [them]2054-the boys — dark as a cellar that [sumach path]1753-sumach path was — and just then [I]0-i found [I]0-i was going to sneeze . It was the meanest kind of luck ! [I]0-i tried to keep it back , but no use—’twas bound to come , and it did come ! [I]0-i was in the lead with [my]0-i pistol raised , and when the sneeze started those scoundrels a - rustling to get out of [the path]1754-the path , [I]0-i sung out , ‘ [Fire boys]1755-fire boys ! ’ and blazed away at the place where the rustling was . So did [the boys]2054-the boys . But [they]2054-the boys were off in a jiffy , [those villains]1757-those villains , and [we]1752-we after [them]2054-the boys , down through [the woods]2157-the woods . [I]0-i judge [we]1752-we never touched [them]2054-the boys . [They]2054-the boys fired a shot apiece as [they]2054-the boys started , but [their]2054-the boys bullets whizzed by and did n’t do [us]1752-we any harm . As soon as [we]1752-we lost the sound of [their]2054-the boys feet [we]1752-we quit chasing , and went down and stirred up [the constables]1759-the constables . [They]2054-the boys got [a posse]1760-a posse together , and went off to guard [the river bank]1761-the river bank , and as soon as it is light [the sheriff]880-the sheriff and [a gang]1763-a gang are going to beat up [the woods]2157-the woods . [[My]0-i boys]1765-my boys will be with [them]2054-the boys presently . [I]0-i wish [we]1752-we had some sort of description of those rascals—’twould help a good deal . But [you]1766-you could n’t see what [they]2054-the boys were like , in the dark , [lad]1644-lad , [I]0-i suppose ? ” “[1644-lad] Oh yes ; [I]0-i saw [them]2054-the boys downtown and follered [them]2054-the boys . ” “[0-i] Splendid ! Describe [them]2054-the boys — describe [them]2054-the boys , [[my]0-i boy]1534-my boy ! ” “[934-one] [One]934-one ’s [the old deaf and dumb Spaniard that ’s ben around [here]551-here]1770-the old deaf and dumb spaniard that ’s ben around here once or twice , and t’other ’s [a mean - looking , ragged]1772-a mean - looking , ragged — ” “[1772-a mean - looking , ragged] That ’s enough , [lad]1644-lad , [we]1752-we know [the men]810-the men ! Happened on [them]810-the men in [the woods back of [the widow]1578-the widow ’s]1775-the woods back of the widow ’s one day , and [they]810-the men slunk away . Off with [you]1644-lad , [boys]183-boys , and tell [the sheriff]880-the sheriff — get [your]1644-lad breakfast tomorrow morning ! ” [[The Welshman]2928-the welshman ’s sons]2944-the welshman ’s sons departed at once . As [they]2944-the welshman ’s sons were leaving [the room]190-the room [Huck]45-huck sprang up and exclaimed : “[880-the sheriff] Oh , please do n’t tell _ any_body it was [me]0-i that blowed on [them]810-the men ! Oh , please ! ” “[0-i] All right if [you]0-i say it , [Huck]45-huck , but [you]0-i ought to have the credit of what [you]0-i did . ” “[0-i] Oh no , no ! Please do n’t tell ! ” When [the young men]425-the young men were gone , [the old Welshman]2910-the old welshman said : “[810-the men] [They]810-the men wo n’t tell — and [I]0-i wo n’t . But why do n’t [you]0-i want it known ? ” [Huck]45-huck would not explain , further than to say that [he]45-huck already knew too much about [one of [those men]2949-those men]2948-one of those men and would not have [the man]492-the man know that [he]45-huck knew anything against [him]45-huck for [the whole world]2432-the whole world — [he]45-huck would be killed for knowing it , sure . [The old man]2929-the old man promised secrecy once more , and said : “[0-i] How did [you]0-i come to follow [these fellows]1779-these fellows , [lad]1644-lad ? Were [they]1779-these fellows looking suspicious ? ” [Huck]45-huck was silent while [he]45-huck framed a duly cautious reply . Then [he]45-huck said : “[1779-these fellows] Well , [you]0-i see , [I]0-i ’m a kind of a hard lot,—least [everybody]490-everybody says so , and [I]0-i do n’t see nothing agin it — and sometimes [I]0-i ca n’t sleep much , on account of thinking about it and sort of trying to strike out a new way of doing . That was the way of it last night . [I]0-i could n’t sleep , and so [I]0-i come along upstreet ’bout midnight , a - turning it all over , and when [I]0-i got to [that old shackly brick store by [the Temperance Tavern]1783-the temperance tavern]1782-that old shackly brick store by the temperance tavern , [I]0-i backed up agin the wall to have another think . Well , just then along comes [these two chaps]1784-these two chaps slipping along close by [me]0-i , with something under [their]1784-these two chaps arm , and [I]0-i reckoned [they]1784-these two chaps ’d stole it . [One]934-one was a - smoking , and [t’other one]1786-t’other one wanted a light ; so [they]1784-these two chaps stopped right before [me]0-i and the cigars lit up [their]1784-these two chaps faces and [I]0-i see that [the big one]1787-the big one was [the deaf and dumb Spaniard]1788-the deaf and dumb spaniard , by [his]1787-the big one white whiskers and the patch on [his]1787-the big one eye , and [t’other one]1786-t’other one was [a rusty , ragged - looking devil]1790-a rusty , ragged - looking devil . ” “[1790-a rusty , ragged - looking devil] Could [you]0-i see the rags by the light of the cigars ? ” This staggered [Huck]45-huck for a moment . Then [he]45-huck said : “[0-i] Well , [I]0-i do n’t know — but somehow it seems as if [I]0-i did . ” “[0-i] Then [they]1784-these two chaps went on , and [you]0-i — ” “[0-i] Follered ’em — yes . That was it . [I]0-i wanted to see what was up — [they]1784-these two chaps sneaked along so . [I]0-i dogged ’em to [the widder]1791-the widder ’s stile , and stood in the dark and heard [the ragged one]1792-the ragged one beg for [the widder]1791-the widder , and [the Spaniard]1794-the spaniard swear [he]1794-the spaniard ’d spile [her]1792-the ragged one looks just as [I]0-i told [you]0-i and [[your]0-i two]1795-your two — ” “[1794-the spaniard] What ! [The _ deaf and dumb _ man]1796-the _ deaf and dumb _ man said all that ! ” [Huck]45-huck had made another terrible mistake ! [He]45-huck was trying [his]45-huck best to keep [the old man]2929-the old man from getting the faintest hint of who [the Spaniard]1794-the spaniard might be , and yet [his]45-huck tongue seemed determined to get [him]45-huck into trouble in spite of all [he]45-huck could do . [He]45-huck made several efforts to creep out of [his]45-huck scrape , but [the old man]2929-the old man ’s eye was upon [him]45-huck and [he]45-huck made blunder after blunder . Presently [the Welshman]2928-the welshman said : “[1796-the _ deaf and dumb _ man] [[My]0-i boy]1534-my boy , do n’t be afraid of [me]0-i . [I]0-i would n’t hurt a hair of [your]1534-my boy head for all [the world]328-the world . No — [I’d]0-i protect [you]1534-my boy — [I’d]0-i protect [you]1534-my boy . [This Spaniard]1799-this spaniard is not deaf and dumb ; [you]1534-my boy ’ve let that slip without intending it ; [you]1534-my boy ca n’t cover that up now . [You]1534-my boy know something about [that Spaniard]2771-that spaniard that [you]1534-my boy want to keep dark . Now trust [me]0-i — tell [me]0-i what it is , and trust [me]0-i — [I]0-i wo n’t betray [you]1534-my boy . ” [Huck]45-huck looked into [the old man]2929-the old man ’s honest eyes a moment , then bent over and whispered in [his]2929-the old man ear : “[1801-a spaniard] ’ Tain’t [a Spaniard]1801-a spaniard — it ’s Injun [Joe]100-injun joe ! ” [The Welshman]2928-the welshman almost jumped out of [his]2928-the welshman chair . In a moment [he]2928-the welshman said : “[100-injun joe] It ’s all plain enough , now . When [you]1534-my boy talked about notching ears and slitting noses [I]0-i judged that that was [your]1534-my boy own embellishment , because [white men]1802-white men do n’t take that sort of revenge . But an Injun ! That ’s a different matter altogether . ” During breakfast the talk went on , and in the course of it [the old man]2929-the old man said that the last thing which [he]2929-the old man and [[his]2929-the old man sons]2933-his sons had done , before going to bed , was to get a lantern and examine the stile and its vicinity for marks of blood . [They]2961-they found none , but captured a bulky bundle of — “[1803-burglar] Of _ what _ ? ” If the words had been lightning [they]2961-they could not have leaped with a more stunning suddenness from [Huck]45-huck ’s blanched lips . [His]2929-the old man eyes were staring wide , now , and [his]2929-the old man breath suspended — waiting for the answer . [The Welshman]162-the welshman started — stared in return — three seconds — five seconds — ten — then replied : “[1803-burglar] Of [burglar]1803-burglar ’s tools . Why , what ’s the _ matter _ with [you]1534-my boy ? ” [Huck]45-huck sank back , panting gently , but deeply , unutterably grateful . [The Welshman]2928-the welshman eyed [him]45-huck gravely , curiously — and presently said : “[1803-burglar] Yes , [burglar]1803-burglar ’s tools . That appears to relieve [you]1534-my boy a good deal . But what did give [you]1534-my boy that turn ? What were _ [you]1534-my boy _ expecting [we]1805-we ’d found ? ” [Huck]45-huck was in a close place — the inquiring eye was upon [him]45-huck — [he]45-huck would have given anything for material for a plausible answer — nothing suggested itself — the inquiring eye was boring deeper and deeper — a senseless reply offered — there was no time to weigh it , so at a venture [he]45-huck uttered it — feebly : “[1534-my boy] Sunday - school books , maybe . ” [Poor Huck]45-huck was too distressed to smile , but [the old man]2929-the old man laughed loud and joyously , shook up the details of [his]2929-the old man anatomy from head to foot , and ended by saying that such a laugh was money in [a man]208-a man ’s pocket , because it cut down [the doctor]614-the doctor ’s bill like everything . Then [he]2929-the old man added : “[1534-my boy] [Poor old chap]1806-poor old chap , [you]1806-poor old chap ’re white and jaded — [you]1806-poor old chap ai n’t well a bit — no wonder [you]1806-poor old chap ’re a little flighty and off [your]1806-poor old chap balance . But [you]1806-poor old chap ’ll come out of it . Rest and sleep will fetch [you]1806-poor old chap out all right , [I]0-i hope . ” [Huck]45-huck was irritated to think [he]45-huck had been [such a goose and betrayed such a suspicious excitement]2966-such a goose and betrayed such a suspicious excitement , for [he]45-huck had dropped the idea that the parcel brought from [the tavern]1687-the tavern was the treasure , as soon as [he]45-huck had heard the talk at [[the widow]1578-the widow ’s stile]2969-the widow ’s stile . [He]45-huck had only thought it was not the treasure , however — [he]45-huck had not known that it wasn’t — and so the suggestion of a captured bundle was too much for [his]45-huck self - possession . But on the whole [he]45-huck felt glad the little episode had happened , for now [he]45-huck knew beyond all question that that bundle was not _ the _ bundle , and so [his]45-huck mind was at rest and exceedingly comfortable . In fact , everything seemed to be drifting just in the right direction , now ; the treasure must be still in [No . 2]2786-no . 2 , [the men]810-the men would be captured and jailed that day , and [he]45-huck and [Tom]46-tom could seize the gold that night without any trouble or any fear of interruption . Just as breakfast was completed there was a knock at the door . [Huck]45-huck jumped for [a hiding - place]2972-a hiding - place , for [he]45-huck had no mind to be connected even remotely with the late event . [The Welshman]2928-the welshman admitted [several ladies]2974-several ladies and [gentlemen]2975-gentlemen , among them [the Widow Douglas]71-the widow douglas , and noticed that [groups of [citizens]1446-citizens]2976-groups of citizens were climbing up [the hill]2700-the hill — to stare at the stile . So the news had spread . [The Welshman]162-the welshman had to tell the story of the night to [the visitors]441-the visitors . [The widow]1578-the widow ’s gratitude for [her]1578-the widow preservation was outspoken . “[0-i] Do n’t say a word about it , [madam]1807-madam . There ’s another that [you]1807-madam ’re more beholden to than [you]1807-madam are to [me]0-i and [[my]0-i boys]1765-my boys , maybe , but [he]1809-he do n’t allow [me]0-i to tell [his]1809-he name . [We]1810-we would n’t have been [there]2038-there but for [him]1809-he . ” Of course this excited a curiosity so vast that it almost belittled the main matter — but [the Welshman]2928-the welshman allowed it to eat into the vitals of [[his]2928-the welshman visitors]2982-his visitors , and through [them]2982-his visitors be transmitted to [the whole town]1114-the whole town , for [he]2928-the welshman refused to part with [his]2928-the welshman secret . When all else had been learned , [the widow]1578-the widow said : “[0-i] [I]0-i went to sleep reading in bed and slept straight through all that noise . Why did n’t [you]0-i come and wake [me]0-i ? ” “[0-i] [We]1810-we judged it warn’t worth while . [Those fellows]1812-those fellows warn’t likely to come again — [they]1812-those fellows had n’t any tools left to work with , and what was the use of waking [you]1813-you up and scaring [you]1813-you to death ? [[My]0-i three negro men]1814-my three negro men stood guard at [[your]1813-you house]2363-your house all the rest of the night . [They]1814-my three negro men ’ve just come back . ” [More visitors]2985-more visitors came , and the story had to be told and retold for a couple of hours more . There was no Sabbath - school during day - school vacation , but [everybody]490-everybody was early at [church]533-church . The stirring event was well canvassed . News came that not a sign of [the two villains]2988-the two villains had been yet discovered . When the sermon was finished , [[Judge Thatcher]158-judge thatcher ’s wife]2989-judge thatcher ’s wife dropped alongside of [Mrs. Harper]118-mrs. harper as [she]2989-judge thatcher ’s wife moved down [the aisle]590-the aisle with [the crowd]506-the crowd and said : “[1814-my three negro men] Is [[my]0-i [Becky]86-becky]1816-my becky going to sleep all day ? [I]0-i just expected [she]86-becky would be tired to death . ” “[86-becky] [Your]0-i [Becky]86-becky ? ” “[86-becky] Yes , ” with a startled look—“didn’t[86-becky] [she]86-becky stay with [you]0-i last night ? ” “[86-becky] Why , no . ” [Mrs. Thatcher]159-mrs. thatcher turned pale , and sank into a pew , just as [Aunt Polly]47-aunt polly , talking briskly with [a friend]2992-a friend , passed by . [Aunt Polly]47-aunt polly said : “[86-becky] Goodmorning , [Mrs. Thatcher]159-mrs. thatcher . Goodmorning , [Mrs. Harper]118-mrs. harper . [I]0-i ’ve got [a boy that ’s turned up missing]1817-a boy that ’s turned up missing . [I]0-i reckon [[my]0-i [Tom]46-tom]2379-my tom stayed at [[your]159-mrs. thatcher house]2363-your house last night — one of [you]159-mrs. thatcher . And now [he]46-tom ’s afraid to come to [church]533-church .
