[Tom]46-tom routed [him]45-huck out , told [him]45-huck the trouble [he]45-huck had been causing , and urged [him]45-huck to go [home]197-home . [Huck]45-huck ’s face lost its tranquil content , and took a melancholy cast . [He]45-huck said : “[46-tom] Do n’t talk about it , [Tom]46-tom . [I]0-i ’ve tried it , and it do n’t work ; it do n’t work , [Tom]46-tom . [It]1974-it ai n’t for [me]0-i ; [I]0-i ai n’t used to it . [The widder]1791-the widder ’s good to [me]0-i , and friendly ; but [I]0-i ca n’t stand them ways . [She]1791-the widder makes [me]0-i get up just at the same time every morning ; [she]1791-the widder makes [me]0-i wash , [they]1976-them comb [me]0-i all to thunder ; [she]1791-the widder wo n’t let [me]0-i sleep in [the woodshed]784-the woodshed ; [I]0-i got to wear [them]1976-them blamed clothes that just smothers [me]0-i , [Tom]46-tom ; they do n’t seem to any air git through ’em , somehow ; and they ’re so rotten nice that [I]0-i ca n’t set down , nor lay down , nor roll around anywher ’s ; [I]0-i hain’t slid on a cellar - door for — well , it ’ pears to be years ; [I]0-i got to go to [church]533-church and sweat and sweat — [I]0-i hate [them]1976-them ornery sermons ! [I]0-i ca n’t ketch a fly in there , [I]0-i ca n’t chaw . [I]0-i got to wear shoes all Sunday . [The widder]1791-the widder eats by a bell ; [she]1791-the widder goes to bed by a bell ; [she]1791-the widder gits up by a bell — everything ’s so awful reg’lar a body ca n’t stand it . ” “[45-huck] Well , [everybody]490-everybody does that way , [Huck]45-huck . ” “[46-tom] [Tom]46-tom , it do n’t make no difference . [I]0-i ai n’t [everybody]490-everybody , and [I]0-i ca n’t _ stand _ it . It ’s awful to be tied up so . And grub comes too easy — [I]0-i do n’t take no interest in vittles , that way . [I]0-i got to ask to go a - fishing ; [I]0-i got to ask to go in a - swimming — dern’d if [I]0-i hain’t got to ask to do everything . Well , [I]0-i ’d got to talk so nice it was n’t no comfort — [I’d]0-i got to go up in [the attic]1982-the attic and rip out awhile , every day , to git a taste in [my]0-i mouth , or [I]0-i ’d a died , [Tom]46-tom . [The widder]1791-the widder would n’t let [me]0-i smoke ; [she]1791-the widder would n’t let [me]0-i yell , [she]1791-the widder would n’t let [me]0-i gape , nor stretch , nor scratch , before [folks]1984-folks — ” [ Then with a spasm of special irritation and [injury]—“And[1791-the widder] dad]3326-injury]—“and dad fetch it , [she]1791-the widder prayed all the time ! [I]0-i never see [such a woman]1985-such a woman ! [I]0-i _ had _ to shove , [Tom]46-tom — [I]0-i just had to . And besides , that school ’s going to open , and [I]0-i ’d a had to go to [it]1986-it — well , [I]0-i would n’t stand _ that _ , [Tom]46-tom . Looky - here , [Tom]46-tom , being rich ai n’t what it ’s cracked up to be . It ’s just worry and worry , and sweat and sweat , and a - wishing [you]46-tom was dead all the time . Now these clothes suits [me]0-i , and this bar’l suits [me]0-i , and [I]0-i ai n’t ever going to shake [’em]1987-’em any more . [Tom]46-tom , [I]0-i would n’t ever got into all this trouble if it had n’t ’ a ’ been for that money ; now [you]46-tom just take [my]0-i sheer of it along with [your’n]1988-your’n , and gimme a ten - center sometimes — not many times , becuz [I]0-i do n’t give a dern for a thing ’ thout it ’s tollable hard to git — and [you]46-tom go and beg off for [me]0-i with [the widder]1791-the widder . ” “[46-tom] Oh , [Huck]45-huck , [you]45-huck know [I]0-i ca n’t do that . ’ Tain’t fair ; and besides if [you]45-huck ’ll try this thing just a while longer [you]45-huck ’ll come to like it . ” “[45-huck] Like it ! Yes — the way [I]0-i ’d like a hot stove if [I]0-i was to set on it long enough . No , [Tom]46-tom , [I]0-i wo n’t be rich , and [I]0-i wo n’t live in [[them]1990-them cussed smothery houses]1991-them cussed smothery houses . [I]0-i like [the woods]2157-the woods , and [the river]346-the river , and hogsheads , and [I]0-i ’ll stick to [’em]1994-’em , too . Blame it all ! just as [we]1995-we ’d got guns , and [a cave]1996-a cave , and [all just fixed to rob]1997-all just fixed to rob , here this dern foolishness has got to come up and spile it all ! ” [Tom]46-tom saw [his]46-tom opportunity — “[45-huck] Lookyhere , [Huck]45-huck , being rich ai n’t going to keep [me]0-i back from turning [robber]1998-robber . ” “[45-huck] No ! Oh , good - licks ; are [you]45-huck in real dead - wood earnest , [Tom]46-tom ? ” “[46-tom] Just as dead earnest as [I]0-i ’m sitting here . But [Huck]45-huck , [we]1995-we ca n’t let [you]45-huck into the gang if [you]45-huck ai n’t respectable , [you]45-huck know . ” [Huck]45-huck ’s joy was quenched . “[1995-we] Ca n’t let [me]0-i in , [Tom]46-tom ? Did n’t [you]46-tom let [me]0-i go for [a pirate]754-a pirate ? ” “[46-tom] Yes , but that ’s different . [A robber]1619-a robber is more high - toned than what [a pirate]754-a pirate is — as a general thing . In [most countries]2002-most countries [they]1619-a robber ’re awful high up in [the nobility]2003-the nobility — [dukes and such]2004-dukes and such . ” “[46-tom] Now , [Tom]46-tom , hain’t [you]46-tom always ben friendly to [me]0-i ? [You]46-tom would n’t do that , now , _ would _ [you]46-tom , [Tom]46-tom ? ” “[45-huck] [Huck]45-huck , [I]0-i would n’t want to , and [I]0-i _ do n’t _ want to — but what would [people]756-people say ? Why , [they]756-people ’d say , ‘ Mph ! [[Tom Sawyer]46-tom ’s Gang]1896-tom sawyer ’s gang ! [pretty low characters in]2007-pretty low characters in [it]1896-tom sawyer ’s gang ! ’ [They]756-people ’d mean [you]46-tom , [Huck]45-huck . [You]46-tom would n’t like that , and [I]0-i would n’t . ” [Huck]45-huck was silent for some time , engaged in a mental struggle . Finally [he]45-huck said : “[0-i] Well , [I]0-i ’ll go back to [the widder]1791-the widder for a month and tackle it and see if [I]0-i can come to stand it , if [you]46-tom ’ll let [me]0-i b’long to [the gang]2009-the gang , [Tom]46-tom . ” “[46-tom] All right , [Huck]45-huck , it ’s a whiz ! Come along , [old chap]2083-old chap , and [I]0-i ’ll ask [the widow]1578-the widow to let up on [you]45-huck a little , [Huck]45-huck . ” “[45-huck] Will [you]46-tom , [Tom]46-tom — now will [you]46-tom ? That ’s good . If [she]1578-the widow ’ll let up on some of the roughest things , [I]0-i ’ll smoke [private and cuss private]2012-private and cuss private , and crowd through or bust . When [you]46-tom going to start [the gang]2009-the gang and turn [robbers]1542-robbers ? ” “[46-tom] Oh , right off . [We]2015-we ’ll get [the boys]2054-the boys together and have the initiation tonight , maybe . ” “[2015-we] Have the which ? ” “[2015-we] Have the initiation . ” “[2015-we] What ’s that ? ” “[2017-it] [It]2017-it ’s to swear to stand by [one another]2278-one another , and never tell [the gang]2009-the gang ’s secrets , even if [you]46-tom ’re chopped all to flinders , and kill [anybody]203-anybody and [all [his]203-anybody family]2021-all his family that hurts [one of [the gang]2009-the gang]2022-one of the gang . ” “[0-i] That ’s gay — that ’s mighty gay , [Tom]46-tom , [I]0-i tell [you]46-tom . ” “[46-tom] Well , [I]0-i bet it is . And all that swearing ’s got to be done at midnight , in the lonesomest , awfulest place [you]46-tom can find — [a ha’nted house]1545-a ha’nted house is the best , but [they]1545-a ha’nted house ’re all ripped up now . ” “[1545-a ha’nted house] Well , midnight ’s good , anyway , [Tom]46-tom . ” “[46-tom] Yes , so it is . And [you]46-tom ’ve got to swear on a coffin , and sign it with blood . ” “[46-tom] Now , that ’s something _ like _ ! Why , it ’s a million times bullier than pirating . [I]0-i ’ll stick to [the widder]44-the widder till [I]0-i rot , [Tom]46-tom ; and if [I]0-i git to be [a reg’lar ripper of a robber]2025-a reg’lar ripper of a robber , and [everybody talking ’bout it]2026-everybody talking ’bout it , [I]0-i reckon [she]2027-she ’ll be proud [she]2027-she snaked [me]0-i in out of the wet . ” CONCLUSION So endeth this chronicle . It being strictly a history of [a _ boy _]2028-a _ boy _ , it must stop here ; the story could not go much further without becoming the history of [a _ man]2029-a _ man _ . When one writes a novel about [grown people]2030-grown people , [he]2029-a _ man knows exactly where to stop — that is , with a marriage ; but when [he]2029-a _ man writes of juveniles , [he]2029-a _ man must stop where [he]2029-a _ man best can . Most of [the characters that perform in this book]2031-the characters that perform in this book still live , and are prosperous and happy . Some day it may seem worth while to take up the story of [the younger ones]2032-the younger ones again and see what sort of [men]185-men and [women]186-women [they]2032-the younger ones turned out to be ; therefore it will be wisest not to reveal any of that part of [their]2032-the younger ones lives at present . * * *
